text: hello everyone I am Ankur working in JP Morgan Chase and thank you for joining us Today we will share our experience of
using CVSS We will explore the limitation of CVSS and we will highlight the examples where CVSS fails to truly
reflect the severity of security vulnerabilities We will start with CVSS
and its role in managing managing vulnerabilities We will highlight six operational challenges with the CSS and
discuss our recommendations We will also spend some time on future direction for a vulnerability assessment and share key
takeaways So let's get started We are team JP Morgan I'm part of vulnerability management team and SCI
focus on security architecture Here are our contact details Feel free to reach out with any
questions after the sessions CVSS is current current industry indust
industry standard for scoring security vulnerabilities It's maintained by first org and current version is
4.0 In a typical workflow we identify and report security vulnerabilities and
request a unique tracking number known as CV and then with the help of CSS we can
get the severity ratings The given rating helps prioritization telling
which vulnerabilities should be addressed first Services score help us make
informed decisions and prioritize vulnerabilities Organization often start
by fixing critical security vulnerabilities first and then work on lower ranked
vulnerabilities We have highlighted the key metrics which will be used during
our session We have analyzed the last 10 years trend
that shows the CVS disclosures are growing exponentially and about 18% of
these vulnerabilities are rated as critical needs prioritization Denial of service attacks
are the most common one followed by code execution vulnerabilities These are concerning due to their impact on
security availability and integrity Now sc will take over to discuss the operational challenges Over
to Sy Thanks Um can everybody hear me I think so So I guess we put the title um
scary enough that everybody showed up and filled up the room Right So uh thank you for coming So I'm going to talk
about the six operational challenges that we have faced while using CVSS in our work life Right Again we are
obligated to mention that this is obviously not JP Morgan's view This is our own view and the research that we have done uh as part of our work So we
have six challenges that we will go through and we have divided them into three groups The first two are things
that are are challenges that you can identify by looking at vectors within
the CVSS if you're familiar with those and I'll take you through those The next two we can't really identify them
through the vectors but there are certain patterns that we will put forward and we don't believe it's fully
solved We have just started the journey and we will you know look at improving it And the final two are actually big
large challenges that we have not managed to solve and we are bringing to the community to try and help and
resolve together So having said that the first one is what we are calling the
aggregation pitfall and this stems from the fact that CVS actually uses the most
well-known CIA triad that is used in security Right We're all almost used to security CIA triads We define things in
terms of impacting confidentiality integrity or availability And CVSS uses
those three core items to define the impact of any given vulnerability But in
doing so there's a side effect that we see And the side effect is is it equally
puts weight on all three of the matrix And when you go into CVSS you can select
one of these three values in CVSS either high low or none for each of those
metric But because of the overall aggregation and the waiting what happens is if there's a vulnerability which
impacts a single metric and not the other ones you are bounded uh by by the
formula as to the maximum score you can get So if sorry so if there is if there
happens to be a situation where there's a vulnerability with only a high for confidentiality and none for integrity
and availability the maximum score you can get out of this is 8.6 but generally
we see that these vulnerabilities tend to be around 7.5 Here's an example So
during covid we had a vulnerability released which was uh the citricx netcaler vulnerability which actually
impact the availability of the system right it had no impact on the integrity
or the confidentiality and the rating that this vulnerability got was only high around 7.5 score So the problem
with this is many enterprises use the scoring as a way to prioritize the vulnerability and go and fix it If you
end up getting scores which are artificially low despite having a huge impact you might not even meet the
threshold of you know fixing it early or quickly In this case it was definitely serious because it was during COVID we
were all working from home and it could really stop the remote working situation in many
companies So is this a one-off thing or is it common So we looked at the data and the data shows that even if you look
at the last year alone there's about two and a half thousand vulnerabilities which follow this pattern So they scored
high on one of the metric but the other two had an impact of none It is very
possible that these would be scored 7.5 or below and would not meet the threshold that many companies use to
prioritize vulnerabilities So this is one of the challenges that we have seen again and again in when vulnerabilities
come through So what we are proposing is um that firstly people be aware of this
situation right that there can be low vulnerabilities which can be very highly impactful and there are certain patterns
that you can look for So for example if you see those three value combinations a high and none none then that is a
telltel sign that this may be happening with this CVE and is getting an artificially low score and you probably
want to look at those specifically to rep prioritize them according to your enterprises
appetite Uh moving on to the next one So CVS score uses a formula right And that
formula is you know if you have read in depth is fairly simple and yet complicated because it uses a lot of um
parameters and variables in there which have been fixed And when we looked at it carefully we saw that there are certain
cases where the score has a bit of a discrepancy in how it turns out uh the base metric versus the final
result And this discrepancy happens to be very very small Right Generally we
get a difference of about 0.1 which is 1% Now seems very very low and not
interesting enough but what does happen in certain cases that might actually trigger those boundaries at which you're
sitting and prioritizing your vulnerabilities So instead of doing an SLA of 14 days you might push it out to
an SLA of 90 days And this is why it's good to be aware of the situation that might happen to you So this is an
example and if you pull up the CVE uh CVSS calculate which tells you the score
this is what you would see that for that particular vulnerability exactly the same values the CVE score comes out as
nine but the final results come out as 9.1 Again this is the particular pattern that causes it Is this the only pattern
that causes it No This is the first one we found There were other patterns which we put in our paper which were also uh
possibly causing the same issue And the the thing with this one is it's not very
very common right So when we looked at the data we only found a handful of these cases that happened last year
right That pattern was only 31 times out of all the about 20,000 CVS published
Now is that again like I said that is not the only pattern There are other patterns that causes the same issue
where there's a bit of discrepancy and cause and can cause the number to jump between the boundaries that an
organization may be using for their prioritization
So again like the last one we're giving the pattern out and we're asking you guys to be on the lookout for these so
that you can match the incoming CVS against these patterns and see if there are CVS that are causing these boundary
jumps which are either causing you to put an artificially high amount of uh resources on it or low one right
depending on which way it's going The third one is missing dependencies So now we're moving away
from actual patterns in vectors that you can look for to things that you can look
inside the CV CVs form So the missing dependency is a significant
problem CV uh CVSS does not deal with well with the fact that some CVEes
require dependencies right having the vulnerability not in a system is not enough You have to have the right
conditions for that vulnerability to be exploited These can be requirement for network and access control certain kind
of configuration or dependencies or even user privileges in some cases So if we looked at this example
this is a vulnerability from Citrix netcaler which actually uh was rated critical by the vendor and can allow for
large amount of memory buffer overflow data to be read and session tokens to be
exposed to hackers But this can only happen in certain configuration settings
where the item has been configured to be a gateway So if this does not happen and
if this is not configured as so in your organization should this be a critical vulnerability Now CVSS does not allow us
to see or define the dependencies within our within the CVS which can cause an
artificially high number and causing resource allocations in the wrong places
Now we looked at the data again in 2023 Again this cannot be pattern based right
Because there is no specific metric that captures the dependency It's within the description of the CVS itself So when we
looked at a few keywords such as configured when should which are indicative of dependencies that need to
exist within the environment we found that a significant number of CVS even in 2023 had those keywords Right It's about
6 7,000 of them So what we're really looking to do is to get an understanding
of how uh we can work together to form a better approach of extending CVS to
incorporate these dependencies So going back to what we did we looked
at the three keywords but now with the and this was last year to be honest and now with the advent of uh LLM and the
progress our next project is going to be to feed all the CVE through the LLM
process and figure out where and how can we identify better the dependencies that are required in each CV to be executed
within the environment so that we're not allocating resources but it's not
required The fourth one I I I'm sure all of you have been using CVSS or
prioritization some vulnerability in some sort or another and this will resonate if you have been using it So
there's a specific metric inside CVSS that requires or can allow you to use ex
to define what is the maturity of the code exploit that exists in the wild Now
this is interesting because when you look at it it seems very very good thing to have You can define what type of um
what is the rating for the exploit that is available Is it unknown Is it high Is
it functional Is it proof of concept or is it unproven and based on that the score should get adjusted So the idea is
that if you and there is numerical values associated with it but the idea is that if you don't know about it if
it's not defined or if it's high then the score does not get impacted but if your exploit is unproven then you
multiply the score with 0.91 hence reducing it by 9% If your exploit is uh
proof of concept then it reduces by 6% Good idea right because you reduce the score you put less less emphasis and
resources on it The problem happens is that how do we know what is the maturity
of exploit at any given time So this information is highly fragmented right
There is no comprehensive data that tells you what is the current state accurately of a given exploit at any
time And it's obviously a rapid and dynamic environment which keeps on changing And this is an example So there
was a um there was a vulnerability in the pro progress software which led to
um incidents of well-known customers published in the media and over a period
of 10 days from June 2nd to June 12th the CVE the the the CVS's value thrashed
a lot right it went from 9.8 down to 9.0 zero back to 9.3 and this is based on
the input that you would have or have known about the um you know the quality
of the exploit at that time Now is this real We don't know right We don't really know the quality of the exploits at any
time We're making a guess And in reality tracking this requires enormous amount
of effort right When we looked at it when we looked at the reference data sources for how do we find out what is
the range of a what is the what is the effectiveness of a exploit at any time there was about four and a half like 400
over 400,000 data points that you would need to read and parse and figure out what is it at any time Given the
situation the likelihood of you being actually able to capture the rating or
the quality of an exploit at any time is very very low and it's very difficult to do and execute So in our case our
recommendation is that until and unless we have specific data sources that can
provide the quality of inputs that we need we should avoid using this the
chances are you are going to lower the score artificially and you know miss vulnerabilities that should be
prioritized higher because of the threshing that happens within the environment Moving on to the fifth one
This is where we think it's a hard challenge that has not been solved right and it's nothing to do with patterns but
it's to do with things that we know well but have not been able to capture or associate in our
scoring APS or threat actors are well known We know nation state actors We talk about them all the time There's
about 200 that are in global presence and attract at any time This is an example of Cozy Bear You know there's
different sources such as MITER which tells you the techniques they're using um you know the industries that are
being targeted the countries that are being targeted even sources that tell you the CVS that might be linked to this
actors What we don't have is the ability to incorporate this into the CVS's
scoring right We don't know how to incorporate this data and improve the
scoring and the prioritization Now there is ongoing work right So for example MITER gives you a
bit of information about association of techniques and exploits with actors Um
Kev publishes exploited CVES and recently EPSS has made the most advances
in this with trying to come up with an exploitability score for every CVE which
is excellent What is missing in all of this is how do we incorporate that into
the CVSS framework to impact vulnerabilities So I have a vulnerability score of 9.5 I have a EPSS
score of 1.2 Right How do I combine those together How do we use that information that is completely missing
and that is a problem that we want to work on in the future and we think it's a big enough problem that the community
needs to pick this up and start forming a solution for right so we have advances in EPSS we have advances in CVSS but how
do we march them together the final one is I think very
crucial given where we are today and the amount of remote working and you know
video conferencing and all the techn technologies that we use today Privacy does not
um come packaged within the CVSS framework We have confidentiality but
there is no space for privacy explicitly within the CVSS framework What do we
mean by that A well-known vulnerability that happened back in a few years ago was the
Zoom vulnerability And Zoom as we know is widely used by many companies and organizations to work remotely now right
right with about 300 million active users in 2024 So there was a vulnerability in Zoom which was rated
medium which had the ability to turn on the camera and get uh users to join any
call from the browser without an intervention from the user Right So these are serious events not only in
terms of confidentiality but impacting the privacy of participants who are using Zoom So how do we get CVSS to pay
more attention to the privacy impact on people rather than just the
confidentiality as a whole And here is the data that shows that this is lagging behind right So if
we look at 2023 there's about 20,000 vulnerabilities published right With uh
an impact showing in confidentiality However there was only 89 cases where we found the word privacy
stuck inside the description and the numbers look even lower if you look to the left hand side as the trend goes So
yes there seems to be analysts and and uh reviewers picking up the fact that
there is a previous impact but it is not prominent within the CVSS framework as to give it the right amount of scoring
and prioritization that we need So this is follows the same approach as
the APS that we need to extend the framework and we need community support to start working on this solution so
that we can get to a stage where previously takes a front row in CVSS Okay So this was all about CVSS3
and like I said we did this work last year when CVSS4 was just being launched but it was not there yet The data was
not available so we could not do much with it But when we did the definitions
were there and the formulas were there and the specifications were there although it was in draft at that time
but it was there So when we looked at the definitions and it hasn't changed by the way when we looked at the
definitions and we thought okay does CVSS4 solve all these problems that we are trying to identify does it f solve
the aggregation problem does it solve the privacy problem does it solve the rest of the problems we talked about we
saw that CVSS4 did make a lot of advancements it made a lot of advancements in the area of supplemental
uh metric groups which were more targeted at safety critical systems now that we have self-driving cars uh you
know you know autonomous uh items going on in our lives those are the places
that the vulnerabilities are targeting they were not fixing the same kind of challenges that we were seeing right and
even with CVSS4 we are likely to be in the same place uh with the same challenges of course we need to look at
the lot more data as the data is coming out to see if any of those have been truly solved but from the definition
wise it does not look like that those challenges have been addressed So what are we really thinking So we are
thinking that we need an extension Now we don't know if this is in terms of extending CBSS itself add-on framework
or something else But the things that we think are really missing in this thing is the association of APS How do we
incorporate the findings that threat actors are actively exploiting a
vulnerability How do we incorporate that into our prioritization How do we incorporate the fact that companies and
enterprises might have environmental dependencies where the CVEes don't matter right How do we give them the
opportunity to incorporate that cleanly so that it can be done It's not that it's not done today is done very
manually by parsing and deciding whether this applies to you But how do we put that into the framework How do we
incorporate the privacy bit into the framework so that we're not only worrying about confidentially as an
umbrella but looking at humans who might have previous impact and lastly this is
I think an enterprisewide need how do we give the framework and approach to say
whether it's um attached to critical business services or not now I know when we have the FAQ section we will probably
argue that some of these are beyond the CVE itself and goes into the prioritization based based on the
context of the company or the enterprise where the vulnerability occurs But that's okay right I'm not saying CVS is
wrong What I'm saying is we need extensions to the framework to make it more user friendly in the environment
that's it's really targeted for right Just knowing the fact that our vulnerability has a score does not work
in an enterprise context when we are trying to prioritize vulnerabilities and spend resources on fixing it
So what are the key takeaways that we were looking at So first two are the
challenges that we posed on the aggregation and the uh and the problem
with the formula So those can be identified by looking at the patterns that you're looking for within the
vectors which we will publish in the materials The next two were the problems
that we identified around um sorry around dependencies and um how
can we identify dependencies from the CVE and the last two are the ones we
talked about how do we extend the framework to account for APS and how do we take privacy impact into
consideration So in overall these were our initial findings from the day-to-day operations that we do and our dealings
with CVSS and we felt that it was important for us to publish the findings we had in terms of the patterns that we
were noticing and the issues that we were seeing So and our ask is to for the
community to be aware of this and so that we can all work together to extend the prioritization framework of
vulnerabilities so that we can uh you know do the right impact for vulnerabilities that are coming out in
the future So I'll stop here and take any questions that you
have Thank you Uh if you could go to the I think we need to go to the mic That's what we
were told
